I am very pleased to have as my guest today Mr. Marcel Grilli, program
advisor for the International Department of NHK. In addition to hi*
programming duties with the government-operated radio station in Tokyo*
Mr, Grilli writes the musical reviews for the JAPAN TIMES and has gained
a considerable reputation in Japan as a chronicler and critic of musical
performances and events in Japan* Let's start out by asking you, Mr.
Grilli to tell us something about contemporary Japanese music from an
historical point of view.
( discusses the importation of Western music duiing the Meiji Period
and the internationalization of Japanese music. Also mentions a few
instruments; the samisen; the shakuhachi; the koto.
Bringing us right up to date, Mr. Grilli* we have a new symphony
organization. The Japan America Philharmonic Orchestra which made its
debut not long ago. Tell us something about this combined effort.
The orchestra consists of two halves of unequal size and complexionâ€”
a string body of 60 Japanese musicians, and an American group of 36
wind and percussion players. John Barnett ( ass't conductor of the
Los Angeles Symphony has welded this group together). But there are two
more orchestras on the scene: the ABC Symphony; the Nippon Philharmonic.
Altogether there are six major professional orchestras operating in Tokyo.
I suppose ballet and opera are also included in the repertoires.
How are these orchestras financed., who really picks up the tab?
